block.p: New York State's economy has continued to grow over the last year, with private-sector employment up and unemployment rates down both downstate and upstate, the state's chief economist said yesterday.

The economist, Stephen Kagann, said that the gains over the last 12 months continued a turnaround in the state's economy that began downstate in 1996 and upstate in 1997. He said that the upstate improvement was often overlooked in discussions of the state's economic situation.

New York State's economy has continued to grow over the last year, with private-sector employment up and unemployment rates down both downstate and upstate, the state's chief economist said yesterday.

The economist, Stephen Kagann, said that the gains over the last 12 months continued a turnaround in the state's economy that began downstate in 1996 and upstate in 1997. He said that the upstate improvement was often overlooked in discussions of the state's economic situation.

Mr. Kagann said that private employment last month was higher statewide by nearly 160,000 jobs, or 2.3 percent, over June 1999. He said the increase was 2.5 percent downstate -- New York City and its suburbs -- and 1.8 percent upstate. The national growth rate is 2.2 percent.
The statewide unemployment rate, seasonally adjusted, ''fell sharply to 4.5 percent in June 2000 from 5.3 percent in June 1999,'' Mr. Kagann said, higher than the current 4 percent rate nationally.
